description:
Bordetella avium is a Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that primarily infects birds. It is a member of the Bordetella genus, which includes several species that are known to cause respiratory diseases in various hosts.

Bordetella avium is the causative agent of turkey coryza, also known as bordetellosis or rhinotracheitis, a highly contagious respiratory disease affecting turkeys and other avian species. The bacterium primarily colonizes the upper respiratory tract of the host, leading to symptoms such as nasal discharge, coughing, sneezing, and difficulty breathing.

The pathogenesis of Bordetella avium involves the production of various virulence factors, including adhesins and toxins, which enable the bacterium to adhere to and damage the respiratory epithelial cells, ultimately leading to the development of the disease. Outbreaks of Bordetella avium infections can have significant economic implications for the poultry industry, particularly in turkey production, due to increased mortality, reduced growth, and decreased egg production.

Effective prevention and control of Bordetella avium infections in poultry often involve a combination of biosecurity measures, vaccination, and appropriate antibiotic treatment strategies, which are crucial for maintaining the health and productivity of affected avian populations.
